title: Optimized protocol for the generation of an orthotopic colon cancer mouse model and metastasis
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Preparation of cells for injection (day 0)
Timing: 10–30 min
Timing: 10 min (for step 1)
Timing: 30 min (for step 2)
This section describes the preparation of cells that will be injected into the mouse colon.
Note: We injected 0.5 million cells (SW480 or tumoroids) per mouse.
Prepare cells from lines.
Remove cell culture medium by aspiration using a 2 mL pipette.
Wash cells with 5 mL of room temperature PBS.
Detach cells by adding 3 mL of Tryplee Express to a T75 cm2 flask.
Incubate cells at 37°C until they detach.
Note: It takes approximately 3–5 min, depending on cell type.
Add 15 mL of culture media containing 10% FBS to inactivate Tryplee Express.
Count cells:
Take 10 μL of cell suspension and add 10 μL of trypan blue.
Deposit this mix on cell counting chamber slides and count cells with cell counter.
Calculate the volume of cells needed to obtain 0.5 × 106 cells in 100 μL that will be injected in each mouse.
Note: Routinely, cell viability is above 95%. If cell viability is less than 80%, do not use these cells.
Spin down cells for 3 min at 231 g.
Discard the supernatant and resuspend cells in 100 μL for each mouse of a solution made of 50:50 culture medium (DMEM without FBS) and Matrigel on ice.
Keep cells on ice until injection into mice.
Note: In our experience, 2 h of waiting did not affect tumor engraftment.
Prepare cells from tumoroids.
Detach Matrigel drops by scratching using the tip of a 1 mL pipette.
Aspirate the drop and medium using a 1 mL pipette.
Transfer all drops to a 15 mL tube. Then add medium until 10 mL to balance the centrifuge.

Spin down cells for 10 min at 450 g at room temperature.
Note: room temperature is in range of 19°C–22°C.
Aspirate the supernatant.
Add 1 mL of room temperature Tryplee Express to the pellet.
Incubate for 3 min at 37°C, 5% CO2, then assess under the cell culture microscope that tumoroids are dissociated into single cells or small clusters.
Add 5 mL medium to inactivate Tryplee Express.
Count cells:
Take 10 μL of cell suspension and add 10 μL of trypan blue.
Deposit this mix on cell counting chamber slides and count cells with cell counter.
Calculate the volume of cells needed to obtain 0.5 × 106 cells in 100 μL that will be injected in each mouse.
Note: If there are small clusters, count the cells in each cluster. If cell viability is less than 80%, do not use these tumoroids.
Spin down cells for 10 min at 450 g at room temperature.
Discard the supernatant and resuspend cells in 100 μL for each mouse of a solution made of 50:50 culture medium (DMEM/F12 without FBS) and Matrigel on ice to prevent premature polymerization of Matrigel.
Keep cells on ice until injection into mice. In our experience, 2 h of waiting did not affect tumor engraftment.
Preparation of mouse (day 0)
Timing: 5 min per mouse
This section describes the preparation of mice before cell injection. The mouse needs to be immobilized and anesthetized. An analgesic is given to mice before the procedure to reduce pain. The colon should be cleaned to remove faces, which is done by gently massaging the mouse’s abdomen.
Anesthetize the mouse with 3% isoflurane and 2 L per minute air flow until it falls asleep.
Once the mouse is sleeping, reduce isoflurane to 2% with an airflow of 0.5 L per minute.

Place tear gel on the eyes of the mice to prevent drying.
Inject 5 mg/kg Carprofen (Rimadyl) analgesic (in 100 μL) diluted in PBS subcutaneously.
Position the mouse on its back with hind legs apart, immobilized with surgical tape (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]A).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2345-Fig1.jpg
Figure 1. Mouse preparation and crypts removal
(A) Anesthetized mouse is placed on its back and kept under isoflurane. The mouse’s legs are immobilized with the tape.
(B) The interdental brush is immersed in an EDTA solution heated to 50°C for 30 s.
(C) The interdental brush is gently inserted into the mouse’s anus and advanced for 1,5 cm into the colon.
(D) The interdental brush is gently removed and immersed in a 1.5 mL Eppendorf tube containing PBS.
(E) Removed crypts visualized under EVOS M5000 microscope. Scale bar, 100 μm.
(F) High magnification of a crypt isolated from a mouse colon. Scale bar, 25 μm.
Remove feces present in the colon by gently massaging the mouse’s abdomen.
Note: You should feel with fingers that the colon is empty.
Critical: This step is essential because unremoved feces in the distal part of the colon may prevent the cells from attaching to the colonic mucosa. Feces can also open the anus too quickly (which will be obstructed at the end of the experiment using surgical glue) and thus decrease the time of adhesion of cells to the colonic mucosa. Do not wash the colon with PBS or similar solutions, as this will dilute the EDTA and the injected cells.
Removal of mouse epithelium (day 0)
Timing: 5 min
This step injures the colonic mucosa to felicitate the attachment of injected cells. The lesions are made by an electric interdental toothbrush soaked into a hot EDTA solution. The same experimenter can prepare both the mice and EDTA.

Pre-heat 0.5 M EDTA, pH8 at 50°C in a water bath 15 min before the start of the experiment.
Immerse the interdental brush for 30 s in the pre-heated EDTA solution (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]B).
Gently insert the interdental brush into the mouse’s anus and advance it 1.5 cm into the colon (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]C).
Turn on the vibration of the interdental brush for 10 s.
Critical: This step is crucial because the number of removed crypts must be sufficient but not excessive. The optimal number of detached crypts is between 2,500 and 5,000 crypts. The pressure exerted on the interdental brush should not be too strong to avoid piercing the colonic wall. In case of bleeding, interrupt the abrasions immediately.
The interdental brush is gently removed and immersed in an Eppendorf tube containing 1.5 mL of PBS (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]D).
Turn on the vibration for 5 s to release the removed crypts (Figures 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]E and 1F).
Evaluate the efficiency of crypt removal:
Pipette 10 μL of PBS containing crypts on a slide.
Count detached crypts under a cell culture microscope.
Multiply this number by 150 to obtain the total number of detached crypts (that are in 1.5 mL PBS).
If there are no or not enough detached crypts, additional abrasions should be performed, assessing the presence of crypts after each abrasion.
Eliminate the residual EDTA by massaging the mouse’s abdomen for 2 min.
Injection of cells in the mouse colon (day 0)
Timing: 5 min
At this stage, cells are deposited in the colonic lumen in the area of the lesions made with the interdental brush.
Mix the cell solution gently to avoid bubbles.
Pipette 100 μL of a solution containing cells and Matrigel using a 200 μL pipette tip.

Insert the pipette tip very gently into the colonic lumen parallel to the colon wall and advance as far as possible (about 1.5 cm).
Pinch the anus and tip of the pipette with tweezers and slowly pipette out cells into the colonic lumen (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]A).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2345-Fig2.jpg
Figure 2. Injection of cells
(A) Solution containing cells and Matrigel is inserted in the colonic lumen.
(B) A drop of biological glue is placed on the anus, and the edges of the anus are pressed with tweezers to prevent the leakage of the solution containing cells.
(C) Mouse is kept with raised pelvis until it wakes up.
Gently remove the pipette tip while continue applying pressure to the clamp to keep the anus closed.
Carefully remove the cone from the anus while maintaining pressure.
Add a drop of surgical glue to close the anus of the mouse (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]B).
Hold the mouse in a position with the raised legs and pelvis until it wakes up (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]C).
After 4 h, verify that the anus of the mice is opened. If not, remove the remaining glue with a damp tissue.
Critical: This step is critical because the cells should not leak from the colonic lumen. The cells should be deposited as far as possible, carefully not to pierce the colon. The volume of deposited glue should be sufficient to hold the anus closed for at least 4 h to allow cell attachment. However, it should not be excessive, ideally self-removed within 4 h.
Live imaging of tumor growth by endoscopy (day 7 to day 90)
Timing: 5 min per mouse

This step allows visualization of tumor growth by colonoscopy (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]). Colonoscopy could be used to observe a healthy, non-damaged colon (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]B), a colon just after damage with an interdental brush (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]C), or to follow tumor growth (Figures 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]D and 3E).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2345-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. Visualization of tumor growth using endoscopy
(A) Animal endoscope composed of a cold light source, a camera control unit, a camera, and a device to inject air to inflate the colon.
(B) The colon observed with an endoscope before the procedure.
(C) Colon observed after brush injury.
(D) Tumor in the colon visualized 15 days after the injury.
(E) Tumor in the colon visualized 37 days after the injury. Scale bar, 1 mm.
Imaging is done starting one week after the transplantation, once every week and up to 3 months, depending on the tumor growth. Mice could be kept alive until the defined humane endpoint, i.e., 50% obstruction of the colonic lumen or deterioration in the general condition of the animal.
Note: Repeating the imaging several times a week should be avoided to limit repeated anesthesia and limit the risk of bleeding in the animals.
Anesthetize mice using 3% isoflurane, 2 L per minute, until it falls asleep.
Reduce isoflurane between 2% isoflurane with airflow of 0.5 L per minute during imaging.
Immobilize the mouse with tape on the hind legs.
Remove feces by abdominal massage as described above.
Note: You should feel with fingers that the colon is empty.
Apply vaseline around the anus to facilitate insertion of the endoscope.

Insert the endoscope gently into the anus while dilating the colon by blowing air into the port using a 50 mL syringe (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]A). The quantity of air depends on how close the colon is. In general, the injected volume of air is around 5 mL.
Move the endoscope throughout the colon gently while recording the movie.
Live imaging of tumor growth intravital IVIS (day 7 to day 90)
Timing: 30 min per mouse
This step allows visualization of tumor growth by IVIS (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]). IVIS could be used to follow the growth of the primary tumor by repeated imaging (Figures 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]C–4E) or to visualize metastasis (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]F). Imaging is done starting one week after the transplantation, once every week and up to 3 months, depending on the tumor growth.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2345-Fig4.jpg
Figure 4. Visualization of tumor growth using IVIS
(A) IVIS composed of a CCD camera, an imaging chamber with a heating shelf, and a gas anesthesia manifold.
(B) Mouse is placed on its back and kept asleep under isoflurane on the heating shelf after the luciferin injection. Mice are imaged at different time points to follow the tumor growth and emergence of metastases.
(C) Mouse before injection of cells.
(D) Mouse just after injection of cells. The detected signal is from injected cells.
(E) Mouse imaged 37 days after cell injection. The detected signal shows a tumor, Scale bar, 1 cm.
(F) Mouse imaged 37 days after cell injection. As the signal from the primary tumor is too strong, obstructing the detection of any potential signal from the metastasis, the mouse’s lower abdomen (colon) is covered with thick paper to block the signal coming from the primary tumor (black square). The detected signal in the upper abdomen represents metastases.

Note: Repeating the imaging several times a week should be avoided to limit repeated anesthesia.
Inject 200 μL of a 15 mg/mL luciferin solution (150 mg/kg of animal) intraperitoneally.
Wait 15 min to ensure consistent photon flux before imaging using IVIS.
Anesthetize the mouse with 3% isoflurane and 2 L per minute air flow until it falls asleep.
Once the mouse is sleeping, reduce isoflurane to 2% with an airflow of 0.5 L per minute (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]B).
Position the mouse on his back in Xenogen Vivovision IVIS lumina II heating chamber (Figures 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]A and 4B). Animals are maintained in the instrument using the integral anesthetic manifold. The stage is at a constant temperature of 37°C, which maintains the mouse’s body temperature.
Using Living Image software, set up exposure time to 1 min, f-stop to 1 and large pixel binning.
Collection of samples (day 30 to day 90)
Timing: 20 min per mouse
Note: Mice could be sacrificed at a defined time point, but not later than the humane endpoint - when the size of the tumor reaches 50% of the colonic lumen. The colon is systematically removed, while the liver and other organs are removed if macroscopic tumors are detected.
Sacrifice mice by cervical dislocation.
Open the abdomen and inspect the organs (liver, lungs, peritoneum) for the presence of macroscopic metastases. Macroscopic metastasis could be observed by eyes as white spots (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]B).
Cut the urogenital system and pelvis, and then excise the anus and the distal part of the colon (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]A).
Inspect colon for presence of tumors.
Note: Tumors could be mistaken by enlarged lymphoid tissues.
Take also other organs if they contain macrometastasis.
Note: Metastases will not be formed if primary tumor grow too fast.
Tissue fixation and embedding (day 30 to day 90)
Timing: 1 day

Fix organs in 25 mL of 4% paraformaldehyde (PFA) dissolved in PBS using 50 mL tube for 1 h at 4°C with gentle shaking.
Decant PFA and wash tissues with PBS for 10 min at 4°C with gentle shaking.
Decant PBS and add 15 mL of 15% sucrose in a 50 mL tube at 4°C with gentle shaking. These sucrose steps remove water from the tissues.
Incubate tissue for 2 h at 4°C.
Decant solution and replace it with 15 mL of 30% sucrose in 50 mL tube.
Incubate tissue for 2 h at 4°C.
Place tissue in plastic 15 × 15 × 5 mm mold and include in OCT at room temperature. Orient the colon vertically (lumen of the colon facing up) with the anus sitting at the bottom of the mold. For other organs, the orientation of the tissue is not important.
Place the mold at −20°C for at least 2 h to let OCT solidify.
Cutting samples using cryostat (day 30 to day 90)
Timing: 30 min per sample
Orient the OCT block with the anus/rectum facing the blade.
Note: The OCT block should be trimmed until reaching the tissue.
Trim the anus and rectum until reaching the tumor that can be seen macroscopically.
Cut colon/tumor into 8 to 10 μm-thick slices.
Note: For other tissues, just trim the OCT and proceed with cutting the tissue into 8 to 10 μm-thick slices.
Transfer the tissue to the slide Super frost + by contact.
Staining samples (day 30 to day 90)
Timing: 2 h
Add 500 μL of a solution containing 25 μg/mL DAPI in PBS to the sections.
Incubate for 30 min at room temperature.

Remove the DAPI solution, add 8 drops of Aquapolymount mounting solution on the tissue section and cover with 24 × 50 mm coverslip.
Leave to dry for at least 1 h before imaging.
Imaging samples (day 30 to day 90)
Timing: 1 h per sample
Image samples using an epifluorescent microscope or, for higher resolution images, a confocal microscope (Figures 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]B and 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]C–6F).
